news_summary: NASA's successful return of the SpaceX Crew-10 mission marks a safe and smooth splashdown off California, showcasing continued progress in crewed space exploration.
news_summary_fr: Le retour réussi de la mission SpaceX Crew-10 de la NASA s'est déroulé en douceur et en toute sécurité au large de la Californie, mettant en évidence les progrès continus de l'exploration spatiale avec équipage.
news_summary_es: El regreso con éxito de la misión Crew-10 de SpaceX marca un amerizaje seguro y sin contratiempos frente a California, mostrando el progreso continuo en la exploración espacial tripulada.

articles.title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 Mission Returns, Splashes Down Off California
articles.summary: Editor’s Note: This release was edited Aug. 9, 2025, to update the International Space Station docking port for the Crew-10 mission. The first crew to splash down in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California as part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program completed the agency’s 10th commercial crew rotation mission to the International Space Station […]
articles.content:
The SpaceX Crew Dragon Endurance spacecraft is seen as it lands with NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov aboard in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of San Diego, Saturday, Aug. 9, 2025. Credit: NASA/Keegan Barber

Editor’s Note: This release was edited Aug. 9, 2025, to update the International Space Station docking port for the Crew-10 mission.

The first crew to splash down in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California as part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program completed the agency’s 10th commercial crew rotation mission to the International Space Station on Saturday.

NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov returned to Earth at 11:33 a.m. EDT. Teams aboard SpaceX recovery vessels retrieved the spacecraft and its crew. After returning to shore, the crew will fly to NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston and reunite with their families.

“Splashdown! Crew-10 is back on Earth from the International Space Station marking the completion of another successful flight,” said NASA acting Administrator Sean Duffy. “Our crew missions are the building blocks for long-duration, human exploration pushing the boundaries of what’s possible. NASA is leading the way by setting a bold vision for exploration where we have a thriving space industry supporting private space stations in low Earth orbit, as well as humans exploring the Moon and Mars.”

The agency’s SpaceX Crew-10 mission lifted off at 7:03 p.m. on March 14, from Launch Complex 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. About 29 hours later, the crew’s SpaceX Dragon spacecraft docked to the Harmony module’s forward-facing port at 12:04 a.m. on March 16. Crew-10 undocked at 6:15 p.m. Aug. 8, to begin the trip home.

During their mission, crew members traveled nearly 62,795,205 million miles and completed 2,368 orbits around Earth. The Crew-10 mission was the first spaceflight for Ayers and Peskov, and the second spaceflight for McClain and Onishi. McClain has logged 352 days in space over her two flights, and Onishi has logged 263 days in space during his flights.

Along the way, Crew-10 contributed hundreds of hours to scientific research, maintenance activities, and technology demonstrations. McClain, Ayers, and Onishi completed investigations on plant and microalgae growth, examined how space radiation affects DNA sequences in plants, observed how microgravity changes human eye structure and cells in the body, and more. The research conducted aboard the orbiting laboratory advances scientific knowledge and demonstrates new technologies that enable us to prepare for human exploration of the Moon and Mars.

McClain and Ayers also completed a spacewalk on May 1, relocating a communications antenna, beginning the installation of a mounting bracket for a future International Space Station Roll-Out Solar Array, and other tasks. It was the third spacewalk for McClain, the first for Ayers, and the 275th supporting space station assembly, maintenance, and upgrades.

Crew-10’s return to Earth follows the Crew-11 mission, which docked to the station on Aug. 2 for its long-duration science expedition.

NASA’s Commercial Crew Program provides reliable access to space, maximizing the use of the International Space Station for research and development, and supporting future missions beyond low Earth orbit, such as to the Moon and Mars, by partnering with private U.S. companies, including SpaceX, to transport astronauts to and from the space station.

Learn more about NASA’s Commercial Crew Program at:

https://www.nasa.gov/commercialcrew

-end-

Joshua Finch / Jimi Russell

articles.reasoning: The article highlights the successful completion of NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 mission, marking a milestone in commercial spaceflight and international cooperation on the ISS. This achievement reflects progress in space exploration and technology, which is inspiring and uplifting for many readers.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 safely returns after International Space Station mission
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA’s Commercial Crew Program partners with private companies like SpaceX to send astronauts to the International Space Station (ISS). This program helps maintain continuous human presence in space while advancing technology and international cooperation.

**What happened** – On August 9, 2025, the SpaceX Crew Dragon Endurance spacecraft safely splashed down in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California, returning four crew members from the ISS. The team included NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, Japan’s astronaut Takuya Onishi from JAXA, and Russian cosmonaut Kirill Peskov from Roscosmos. They landed at 11:33 a.m. Eastern Daylight Time and were quickly recovered by SpaceX vessels.

**Impact** – This mission marked the first time a NASA commercial crew has landed in the Pacific Ocean near California, expanding recovery options beyond the usual Atlantic splashdowns. Successfully completing the 10th commercial crew rotation, this flight continues to strengthen international teamwork on the ISS and demonstrates the reliability of private-public partnerships in space travel.

**What’s next step** – After splashdown, the crew will return to NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston to debrief and reunite with their families. NASA will continue planning future Commercial Crew missions to support ongoing ISS operations and prepare for longer missions to the Moon and Mars.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Crew-10 mission successfully returned astronauts to Earth via a historic Pacific Ocean splashdown, highlighting progress in commercial spaceflight and global collaboration.
articles.personality_title_fr: La mission Crew-10 de SpaceX de la NASA revient en toute sécurité après un séjour à la Station spatiale internationale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le programme Commercial Crew de la NASA travaille avec des entreprises privées comme SpaceX pour envoyer des astronautes à la Station spatiale internationale (ISS). Ce programme permet une présence humaine continue dans l’espace tout en faisant progresser la technologie et la coopération internationale.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 9 août 2025, le vaisseau spatial SpaceX Crew Dragon Endurance a amerri en toute sécurité dans l’océan Pacifique au large de la Californie, ramenant quatre membres d’équipage de l’ISS. L’équipe comprenait les astronautes de la NASA Anne McClain et Nichole Ayers, l’astronaute japonais Takuya Onishi de l’agence spatiale JAXA, et le cosmonaute russe Kirill Peskov de Roscosmos. Ils ont atterri à 11h33 heure avancée de l’Est et ont été rapidement récupérés par des navires SpaceX.

**Impact** – Cette mission a marqué la première fois qu’un équipage commercial de la NASA a amerri dans l’océan Pacifique près de la Californie, élargissant les options de récupération au-delà des habituel amerrissages dans l’Atlantique. En complétant avec succès la 10e rotation commerciale d’équipage, ce vol renforce la coopération internationale sur l’ISS et démontre la fiabilité des partenariats public-privé dans les vols spatiaux.

**Prochaine étape** – Après l’amerrissage, l’équipage retournera au Centre spatial Johnson de la NASA à Houston pour un débriefing et retrouver leurs familles. La NASA poursuivra la planification des futures missions Commercial Crew pour soutenir les opérations continues de l’ISS et préparer des missions plus longues vers la Lune et Mars.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La mission Crew-10 de la NASA est revenue avec succès sur Terre via un amerrissage historique dans l’océan Pacifique, illustrant les progrès des vols spatiaux commerciaux et la collaboration mondiale.
articles.personality_title_es: La misión Crew-10 de SpaceX de la NASA regresa con seguridad tras estancia en la Estación Espacial Internacional
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Programa Commercial Crew de la NASA trabaja con empresas privadas como SpaceX para enviar astronautas a la Estación Espacial Internacional (ISS). Este programa permite una presencia humana continua en el espacio mientras avanza la tecnología y la cooperación internacional.

**Qué pasó** – El 9 de agosto de 2025, la nave espacial SpaceX Crew Dragon Endurance amerizó de manera segura en el Océano Pacífico frente a la costa de California, regresando a cuatro miembros de la tripulación desde la ISS. El equipo incluyó a los astronautas de la NASA Anne McClain y Nichole Ayers, al astronauta japonés Takuya Onishi de JAXA y al cosmonauta ruso Kirill Peskov de Roscosmos. Aterrizaron a las 11:33 a.m., hora de verano del Este, y fueron rápidamente recuperados por embarcaciones de SpaceX.

**Impacto** – Esta misión fue la primera vez que una tripulación comercial de la NASA amerizó en el Océano Pacífico cerca de California, ampliando las opciones de recuperación más allá de los amerizajes habituales en el Atlántico. Al completar exitosamente la décima rotación comercial de tripulación, este vuelo refuerza el trabajo en equipo internacional en la ISS y demuestra la confiabilidad de las asociaciones público-privadas en los viajes espaciales.

**Próximo paso** – Después del amerizaje, la tripulación regresará al Centro Espacial Johnson de la NASA en Houston para una revisión y reunión con sus familias. La NASA continuará planificando futuras misiones Commercial Crew para apoyar las operaciones continuas de la ISS y prepararse para misiones más largas a la Luna y Marte.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La misión Crew-10 de la NASA regresó con éxito a la Tierra mediante un amerizaje histórico en el Océano Pacífico, destacando el avance en vuelos espaciales comerciales y la colaboración global.
articles.image_prompt: A serene seascape at dawn showing a stylized, gently bobbing spacecraft capsule floating peacefully on calm ocean waters near a softly glowing coastline, with four distinct, abstract constellation patterns above representing the diverse international crew, all rendered in warm, natural tones with delicate brushstrokes evoking hope and successful return.
